description.text: space test

This thing was inspired by Thomas Sanladerer's excellent (and fun!) video on the strength of various materials. While it is true you can build anything with a 3D printer, you need to understand the material properties if you're going to print parts as structural members. This part is used to determine tensile (and potentially compression) strength of a 3D printed material.

Print this thing in the material of your choice and then put a drill bit or hex wrench (as shown in the photos)  through one end (to hang it from a vice). You can use the hole in the other end to attach weights and to apply force.   
The cross section is nominally 10 x 10mm (or 100mm^2) in imperial units that is .155 sq inch. You can divide the force applied in pounds by .155 and get PSI or pounds per square inch. The measurement wil be "nominal" as most 3D printers aren't that accurate. In my case one side was 9.93mm and the other 10.15mm making the area nominally .158 square inchs, roughly 2% bigger than spec. If you're trying to be really accurate you can use a caliper to measure to get exact numbers to work from.  
The thing prints one vertical and one horizontal. It does this because the slicer lays now plastic which, from a tensile strength point of view, favors horizontal (long runs) prints rather than layers. In Testing keep the two identified (when not printing with a raft the 'smooth' side will tell you.) so that you can get both the 'vertical' printed tensile strength and the 'horizontal' printed tensile strength.  
Finally, infill has a big impact here, high infill will put more plastic in the cross section, lower infill will do the opposite. At the end of the day it is the total cross sectional area of plastic, and its homogeneity that determines how 'strong' the piece will be in tension (and how crushable in compression).

description.text:
Having trouble finding a replacement toilet paper holder? Print your own! OpenSCAD design allows for adjustment of all parameters (e.g., length of parts). You'll need to obtain a spring from an existing holder, or source one. Simply print, insert the spring into the big tube, slide the smaller tube into the interlocking part and twist!
Now customizable by overall length!
Todo: Figure out why customizer is making the tubes look like cones. Should compile and render in openscad just fine though...

I bought a toilet paper holder from the local thrift store that was too short to fit in the holder.  I had a spare in the house which I measured with some calipers to make the design in OpenSCAD.  Printed using .2mm layer height in ABS and used the spring from the holder that was too short.
A comprehensive overhaul of lens holders and clips compatible with the Diveboard / OpenDive design.

The original OpenDive lens design, while it allowed the flexibility to specifically manipulate the lens for each eye, was exceedingly difficult to precisely setup and to maintain lens position. frma71 made significant improvements to these parts by designing a single holder for both lenses, allowing the focal plane of both lenses to be parallel. I printed her/his lens holders (both the 60mm IPD and the 65mm IPD versions), but found that the bridge between the lenses pressed up against the bridge of my nose when set at optimal focal length. The lens holders on this page, which are a derivative of the holders by frma71, include a 45 degree arch across the bridge with allows the lenses to move closer to the eyes and avoid contact with the user's face when used at the optimal focal length. I modified both the 60mm and 65mm IPD versions, which together should be sufficient for the majority of users according to Wikipedia.

Additionally, I have designed a full set of clips that are compatible with the lens holders that lock them in at the optimal focal length.  Since the original OpenDive visor was designed to handle focal lengths from 30mm - 50mm, I have included 5 sets of these clips allowing for focal lengths of 30mm, 35mm, 40mm, 45mm, and 50mm.  Each set of clips includes small embossed text with the focal length and an arrow to indicate the direction of mounting.  Since the original OpenDive lenses are 25mm diameter and 45mm focal length, these are the lenses and clips included in the attached photos.

Since frma71's holders were designed to be fully compatible with the original OpenDive visor (or any other derivative work which maintains the same lens channels, like my Diveboard v1 Design) the lens holders on this page maintain that same compatibility.
The clips are fully compatible with the lens holders on this page as well as those designed by frma71. They are also be compatible with the original OpenDive visor, as well as any derivative works that maintain the same lens channel dimensions (again, like my Diveboard v1 Design).

The 45 degree arch on the bridge was designed to avoid scaffolding.  The clips require a bit more, but are easily removed.  I printed both holders and clips on a Replicator 2 using PLA.  The lens holders I printed on high (0.1 mm layer height) with 2 shells and 20% infill.  The clips I printed on high (0.1 mm layer height) with 1 shell and 100% infill.

One of the included photos shows how these parts easily integrate with my Diveboard v1 visor. I love the finished look that the clips provide on the outside of the visor. Functionally, this is a dramatic upgrade that turns the Diveboard / OpenDive into a much better experience. Lens adjustments are no longer required and the experience becomes one where you can simply drop this on someone's head and show it off.

I have a 16g CO2 duster and a lot of 12g CO2 canisters ("powerlets", i suppose) around, and I don't want to stock both sizes.The 12g canisters are a little smaller, but by inserting this plastic cup under one it fills the compartment for a 16g and works well.
It was an easy 5-10 minute print, and works well.

This design is most famous for being used in the sci-fi classic film "Blade Runner". It was originally designed by Frank Lloyd Wright for the 1924 Ennis house in Los Angeles, where the design was used on repeating concrete blocks. Also check out my Freeman House Tile, another Frank Lloyd Wright design. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:172787

You may get warping if you don't use a heated build platform. The default STL is 145mm square, but scale it as you choose. You can also scale the z axis independently to get more or less releif on the tile. The sketchup file is included. 
I realize there is already one of these on Thingiverse, but I drew this one independently and it is slightly different and I think slightly more accurate.

title: Da Vinci Z Axis Linear Rod Pillow Block Upgrade

description.text:
First part I have posted of my own Design. This upgrade made a huge difference on my Da Vinci 1.0 print bed removing much of the slop. Even if you don't believe there is much or any you will likely see a difference post upgrade.
White version mounted in pictures is a V1 and only works on lower two mounts vs V4 design printed in red which is designed for upper and lower(only tested lower myself). This part will no longer be updated as I have sent the printer back. I quickly learned the inconsistency of plastic printers isn't going to fly with my OCD and plan to purchase an all metal MakeGear M2 or similar.

I printed this with the Repetier firmware using slic3r so your results may vary but I suggest 100% infill for strength and 0.2-0.3 layer height. Screw/bolt holes will likely need to be cleaned but I've included the 123D file so anyone can mod/remix this as needed.  
The screw I used for the clamp is from a Raptor 50 helicopter plastic frame and measures 2.87mm diameter and 18mm long.

title: Carnifex Hand Cannon (Cut to fit on smaller print beds)

description.text:
This is the updated version of my Carnifex Hand cannon. I've printed off a version of this and I'm documenting my build on several different pages.
http://www.therpf.com/f9/mass-effect-carnifex-prop-solidworks-3d-printing-219469/
That's where you can see most of the work I've put into this, and where you can see how they've worked when I printed them. I cut the main body into smaller parts to fit on smaller print beds, and in the hopes it will reduce warping for those of you who print it. StarJeff is designing a display stand for this, available here:
REUPLOADED FILE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1850891 Update 8-4-2015: I made a second one of these, and gave it to Rana McAnear (the face model for Samara/Morinth). You can see some shots of it on her various social media profiles, and it will hopefully be making the convention rounds with her.

I added a few holes between the parts to stick short pieces of 1.75mm filament in, to help you align the parts as you glue them together. For PLA, I used some plasti-weld cement, which is pretty gnarly fume-wise, and awful for your health. Gets the job done, though, and the parts are physically melted together at the seams.  If you're using ABS, then you can use an acetone-based model cement to accomplish the same thing.  
For a more detailed version of how I've handled the post-print process with the two I've made so far, the link to my build thread on therpf forums has much more information.

I designed this in Solidworks. I started with a rough outline from a blueprint and reference pictures from in-game, then traced it in a sketch, and extruded it to the width I wanted. That gave me the rough outline of it, and the rest of it was a matter of adding more layers of extruded solids or extruded cuts to add details. The curved section was considerably more complex than that, but the main body of it was mostly just 2D shapes stretched to size with details cut in.

The circular holes in the top and bottom of the main body hold 1/4" magnets, as well as one near the top by the battery, to later hold on a scope attachment.
The upper barrel is set to take a press-in threaded insert (http://www.grainger.com/product/Ultrasonic-Insert-1GRL3 is what I used). I'll be modelling and making different attachments that you can screw in using a 3/8-16 bolt. As seen with the fake silencer I've posted in the build thread.

comments.text: For weathering, the most handy thing I picked up was a weathering kit from Tamiya. They come in kind of a powdery pastel kind of substance.  They make a whole bunch of colors, but the colors you'll want are "soot" and "rust" which came in different 3-packs. Most of the highlights were done with just a silver paint that I had leftover. I think it was Testors Aluminum, but about any shiny metallic color works great.  You can get a little carried away with it, and it'll still look okay later. When it's still shiny, it might look a bit much, but once it's good and dry, you can take the foam brush with the kit (or any cheap foam makeup brush, I raided a dollar store for some) and just rub a little of the "soot" black weathering powder over them, and it'll instanty go from super shiny to a satin. You can keep going, and almost make it blend in with the rest of the paint if you want.  The "rust" color looked a little off for me to use very much of it with the base coats I used, but you can certainly try a little with your own paints and see how it looks.   I had some darker brown acrylic colors kicking around, and I used a dab of that here and there in the cracks, wiping it away before it dried, if you want a dirty kind of weathered feel to it.

comments.text: Does this need support when printing?
comments.author: MadDemon64

comments.text: Some of the parts will need support. The main bodies need support for the internal compartments if you print them with the straight cut flat on the print bed. The handle can be printed with the flat bottom on the print bed, and minimal (if any) support required. The curved section needs a little support, if you print it with the curves facing upwards, but the supported part will be covered up after assembly, so any cosmetic damage done seperating the supports isn't a big deal. I tried to model it so that it would take as little support as possible and be covered up where it was needed. Your printing results may vary a bit, depending on your settings and your printer's behaviour on overhangs at these angles.

This servo tray allows you to mount stronger and more precise servos in the ParkZone Radian Pro to improve tail performance.  The stock servos do not center well, which is particularly problematic on the elevator, which must be trimmed precisely for the plane to glide consistently.  
The tray accepts a Hitec HS-82MG for the elevator and a smaller HS-65MG for the rudder.  To mount it in the plane, remove the original servos, test-fit the tray and cut away foam as needed so the tray fits into the bay.  The back of the plate rests on the same surface as the tabs of the original (3W) servos.  Once you have the tray fitting properly, hot glue it in with a bead of hot glue around the edge.  
You may also wish to consider replacing the ESC with one that can provide more current to the servos.

title: Rock Solid Prusa X Axis Mounts / Z Wobble Free

description.text:
Fed up of Z wobble? Tried "floating" X mounts and such? Try the brute force method!
I designed this from the ground up. Lots of attempts at this are derivatives and I felt it needed a fresh approach. I've been using these for about 3 months now, and they're rock solid!
I've completely eliminated Z wobble by:
  • Making the couple between the smooth and threaded rods as solid as possible
  • Moved to M4 threaded rods
  • Created a nut adapter so this X mounting system can use M8 or M4 threaded rod
  • Constrained only one end of the Z threaded rod
  • Made a new Z couple for the M4 threaded rod
    The idea is rather than trying to get the Z rods to float in various other attempts at wobble-free-ness, I constrain the whole X carriage to the Z smooth rods. I then ensure the Z threaded rods can move about as much as they need to by de-constraining one end, and using much thinner rod that can be flexed by the now solid X carriage.
    • -EDIT-
  • Uploaded revised models
  • Added a Nema17 motor standoff, only if you need it.

PLA, no supports, 0.2mm layer height.
Some postprocessing required as everything needs to have a tight fit to be rock solid.
You'll need to remove the built in support from the X motor mount to make room for the belt, and clean up all the vertical holes as they too have built in support.
You also need to ream the X smooth rod holes out with an 8mm drill bit.
I needed to tidy up the channels that allow the X rod clamps to work, you may not have to depending on your printer setup.

comments.text: One last thing,
comments.author: Draggon

comments.text: You can file some of the bridge away if necessary. I didn't design for the belt to run through that part though. I expect most people who are at the stage of chasing Z wobble have fitted motor dampers, so the belt runs through the bit where you removed the built in support. This is homebrew though, I guess a bit of tinkering and adapting is expected to work on your machine. I've uploaded another picture to illustrate.
comments.author: Draggon

description.text: This is a box for the pieces of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:409284

SettlersSW_box.svg is the file to laser cut. Make sure you set the layers up correctly for cut vs etch.   
The half_sub_boxes...pdf's are for printing on paper or light card and cutting out - you will want to leave some tabs on the non-logo side to aid assembly. These can be used for holding the various playing pieces and should fit in the middle slot that isn't for rectangular cards.  
You will need to add hinges to the lid.  
When I cut mine the laser cutter had a bit of an issue so some cuts were recut once or twice so I needed to glue the ends, hopefully it should clip together sufficiently on a clean cut.

author: mgold

description.text:
Spanner Multiple for M3, M4, M5, M6, M7, M8, M10, M12
Almost pocket-sized, lightweight.

Printed with PLA
0.2 mm thickness
2 shells
smg

This is my first attempt at producing a useable and affordable 3D printed microscope for educational use. It is designed to use a low power objective (RMS 20.32 diameter; e.g. 10x - can be bought for ~£15) and a standard low power eye-piece (23.2 mm diameter 10X - ~£10). The images included here were taken with slighly lower power (8X eye-piece and 7X objective taken from a microscope that was no longer needed) using my mobile phone. The focus is adjusted using the main screw thread. The light source is a LED keychain light (costing just 40p) which is easily modified to provide illumination of different colours by replacement of the LED (it is sufficiently bright to excite GFP fluorescence). The stage is moveable and can then be 'locked' into place by just pressing downwards allowing the whole microscope to be lifted up and passed around. The objective thread prints well enough on my Ormerod (0.24mm layer height at 30mm/s) but the first time you screw in the objective take particular care not to cross thread the parts. The stage needs a little bit of a gentle clean with a blade to allow it to slide easily. Obviously it is still work in progress, but the images are perfectly acceptable (see the image captured by holding-up my mobile phone) - despite my deliberate shorter tube length....
I am not entirely happy with the moveable stage and may try a pantogram-type movement system. I could use metal screws, for the adjustments, but I would like to see if I can restrict the non-printable items to just the optical comonents. I plan a cheap web-cam attachment and a series of different stages for trans-illumination and dark field etc.....although the stage isn't required if you just want to look at surfaces of objects.
The design for the ABScope was intended to be as simple as possible and not just a copy of a traditional metal microscope. I hope it does look 'unusual'! Please feel free to comment or make suggestions.

It's a spool holder for Prusa mendels. It looks a bit like a tipi so that's why I named it that. Two of these baby's in combination with a piece of 8mm rod will hold spools up to a radius of 10cm. The feet will 'snap' onto the top of your Prusa and the rod should pop in snugly so this is a complete toolless design!

Print two of the holders. Pop in a piece of rod and in between your spool. Snap the feet onto the top of your printer. Enjoy. Like. Share.
.scad file is included, so you can adjust it if you want, for instance, you could make it slightly higher to accomodate bigger spools.

A shell to enclose my Nexus 7 Qi charger and block out the actinic light from the green charging LED on the side.

I rotated the STL 45 degrees when placing it on the print bed so the legs would print in x-y rather than at 45 degrees. Lots more details on this gadget can be found at: http://tomhorsley.com/hardware/solidoodle/solidoodle-charger.html Of course I could have just stuck electrical tape on the side of the charger, but then I wouldn't have had an excuse to use the 3D printer :-).

comments.text: I've gone through 1 spool of 1kg filament so far, just changed spools and have 4 parts left.  I was trying to print without rafts and scrapped about 6 big pieces doing trial and error on infills and thickness.  Building now with rafts, supports, 5% infill, standard layer thickness (can't remember the default) and everything is turning out great.  Pretty sure I used some of the first spool on half a helmet too though, as well as some other small parts.  It is possible (depending on table size, i'm using a replicator 2) to combine some of the pieces so they print as 1 to save some time.
comments.author: CrazzyChameleon

description.text: A tasty pineapple made digital using hypr3d.com 's image-based 3D reconstruction.

We made this model for a client, but we thought we'd clean it up and make it printable.
We took 36 images -> 450K face digital model -> fill holes using Netfabb Studio Basic -> downsample to 25K faces in Meshlab.  Then we printed a few out on a BFB 3000.  It's a whole pineapple family!
Come check us out at hypr3d.com

comments.text:
I just finished printing and building this frame and i just love it. I modified it but have some ideas on improving this design or maybe the version 2.
I printed all your files upside down so i would not need support then glued the frame pieces together. I took all your files and erased the side walls basically leaving me with flat covers and glued them onto what is now the front. It made for a super strong (impressively strong) boxed frame. I believe leaving the back hollow leads to too much flexing and the covers solved that perfectly. I also chopped up newspaper's in a blender with water and made a pulp to fill the hollow cavity in the center to cut down on noise and deaden the hollow sounding cavity's.
Its so far turned out awesome. I cant wait to fit the rest of the pieces to it and try it out. I will let you know how it works out

remixed_from.author: pefozzy
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade Accessible Belt Drive Extruder

title: Greg's Wade Accessible Belt Drive Extruder, Rev2

description.text:
This is a mash-up of the Greg's Wade extruder and Terawatt Industry's belt drive extruder. It brings the zero backlash advantages of the Terawatt 00str00der design together with a heavy duty, rock solid design.
Note: this is designed for 3mm filament.
I've included the solidworks files for the frame and assembly. You'll have to download the remainder of the solidworks files from the original version of the extruder if you want to fully edit the assembly
This is a remixed version of the original: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:185269
Updates:
-Beefier main frame to avoid cracking around bearings
-Accommodates 2x 608 bearings on the non-drive side of the hobbed bolt for extra stability
-improved nut traps for M4 mounting nuts
-improved stepper mounting plate 2015.10.27 update:
-I added files for the idler- NITEWING76 was kind enough to send me the files for inclusion in this package. 2014.10.01 Update:
-Updated 1.75mm version to allow for more compression of the filament. Also updated the Solidworks .prt file. 2014.09.23 Update:
-Added 1.75mm filament version. I'm not sure if there will still be enough clamping distance available with the idler- if someone tries it, and it works (or doesn't work) please let me know.
-Updated the solidworks part file- it now includes two configurations, the default 3mm and a 1.75mm version.

Components Required:
65T plastic (carbide) GT2 pulley w/8mm bore, flanges, set-screw
17T aluminum GT2 pulley w/5mm bore, flanges, set-screw
GT2 belt, 2mm pitch, 88T, 196mm length, 6mm-with, fiberglass-reinforced, closed-loop
Pulleys and belt can be sourced from stock drive products, Terawatt industries, ebay, etc.
Hobbed Bolt
608 bearings, 4 minimum (3x for hobbed bolt, 1x for idler)
2x M4 x 55 SHCS
2x springs
1x M8 axle or stud for idler pulley
4x M3 SHCS for stepper mount
4x M3 washers for stepper mount
misc other M3 / M4 hardware
Assemble as normal for Greg's style extruder. Use the slots in the stepper mount to tension the belt. Be sure to recalibrate your E steps after installation. You may also have to reverse the direction of your extruder stepper in your firmware. (I did)
Enjoy quieter, backlash-free printing!

title: Finger and Thumb Picks (derived from claud10's design)

description.text:
i added a rib to supplement the stiffness of claudio del valle's excellent thumbpick design, and also rounded some of the corners... i also created a simple finger pick, which i left a bit thick to accommodate a healthy amount of sanding which i think is key to minimizing those "swipe" sounds on the ol' strings....? hopefully i left the poly's simple enough so that it's still easy to tweak for your own purposes! by unpopular demand, a short video of them in action:
http://www.youtube.com/embed/QXw8Oq9koeE

for the thumb pick, i went with medium settings, .2 layer height on my rep2, with sanding to get rid of the ridges on the "picking surface".
not quite sure what is ideal for the finger picks since on my rep2 v7 firmware, smaller layer settings tend to create a blob at the end of the pick which requires filing/sanding.  you can avoid the "blob" a bit on larger layer heights (like the default medium setting of .27) for some reason, but regardless the finger picks will need a lot of sanding to get rid of that "swiping sound".
PS for the finger picks, it boosts playability alot to really file away at that inside edge (inside meaning the side where your finger is), at an angle nearly parallel to the z-axis of the pick to get rid of any sort of "hook feeling" on the strings.

author: brnrd

description.text:
I wanted to make a hook to mount near the door to hang the dog leash, my keys, and a "paw towel" on. I have a cute little pug named doughnut and I thought it would be cool to put a little pug silhouette on it, but then I thought that this might be a good opportunity to utilize the Makerbot "customizer" app for people with other breeds.
I am very new to OpenSCAD, the only other thing I have made is a customizable little tube. However, I am always eager to learn so I started doing some research. I was looking for a way to draw the silhouettes when I stumbled upon dnewman's "Inkscape to OpenSCAD converter v2". http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036
Perfect! I simply vectored my silhouettes in illustrator and used dnewman's Inkscape extension to convert them to .scad.
I am sure there is a better way to make the "options" then the way I did it (feel free to post in the comments). Current Available Breeds: beagle, boston, boxer, bull, chihuahua, dachshund, doberman, german, golden, greyhound, lab, pomeranian, poodle, pug, rottweiler, schnauzer, springer, yorkshire. PS - There are a lot of breeds out there so if you would like me to add one, just let me know. Otherwise, I will be slowly adding more at random.

*Launch in the Customizer app.
  • There will be no rendered object until you select a breed from the drop down.
    • *Select a Breed.
  • Current Available Breeds: beagle, boston, boxer, bull, chihuahua, dachshund, doberman, german, golden, greyhound, lab, pomeranian, poodle, pug, rottweiler, schnauzer, springer, yorkshire.
    • *Create .STL Enjoy! PS - There are a lot of breeds out there so if you would like me to add one, just let me know. Otherwise, I will be slowly adding more at random.

description.text: If you have ever needed to take apart a piece of electronics, you know that you can quickly end up with a pile of assorted screws, nuts, and bolts. Grouping screws in the order they are taken out can help you correctly reassemble parts without ending up with "extra screws". When I worked in the electronics contracting field, we used ice cube trays to organize sets of screws as we removed them. However, they are really bulky, and we rarely ever used the entire tray. This is a much more manageable size, and it has the capacity to hold some larger parts at the back of the tray.
Print at 10% infill, with 1 extra shell and .25mm layer height.

Quick and easy bit for the long oop Heroquest; we somehow lost half a treasure chest - this is the replacement; didn't see any sense to pay $3 for a complete one plus $4 for s/h on eBay... what's with eBay shipping/handling pricing these days??

  • Match two of these and insert with a color/cardboard printout of your favorite treasure chest texture - I recommend Kev's Lounge Paper Prints - Dungeon Furniture Pack.

  • This model includes the pin hole for the weird little barrel bar that was included to hold the two sides together - but it isn't really needed, I've used toothpicks before as well, if you don't glue your inserts to the plastic.

  • Prints flat on its back, no support in just under 15 minutes. Used a little acetone wash to soften the rivets, they are rounded in the original model.

  • This was a good little project to teach kids about tolerances and using digital calipers - modify on Tinkercad as needed depending on thickness of card stock used.

  • This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hNZSizpP4h6

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SDO2mXPhJWU
In this project we’re building an Ultrasonic Ruler!
Inspired by Dune, this Harkonnen pistol is a rare movie prop that was never seen in film.
A stylized enclosure makes this distance sensor into a hand held sonar measuring tape.
The design features a unique handle and a large barrel that fits this project nicely.
In this circuit, the trinket write's the distance to a LED display. The EZ rangefinder is a great sensor for reading proximity and measuring distance.
You can get the electronics for this project from the shop on Adafruit dot com.
The 8 piece design is open source and available to download. It takes about 6 hours to print in PLA filament.
The parts are optimized to printing with no support material and extra details are added to the parts for cinematic aesthetics .
A light coat of silver spray paint gives these pieces that extra shine and gun metal look.
Check out our guide on the Adafruit learning system for a circuit diagram and full tutorial for this project.
The enclosure is designed to secure the components and is fastened together with machine screws.
wire wrap is threaded through the handle and neatly housed behind the stands offs.
Assembly takes just a few hours and the final result is a functioning hollywood inspired replica.
Download our ardunio libraries and demo sketch to program the trinket micro-controller.
What features could you add to this project? Let us know in the comments below.
Full Tutorial on The Adafruit Learning System:
https://learn.adafruit.com/ultrasonic-ruler

title: Marble head of the emperor Caracalla (211-217)

description.text:
I scanned this bust at the British Museum using 123D Catch and my iPhone 5S. I wasn't able to capture the very top of the hair so I reconstructed what I could with MeshMixer.

Marble head of the emperor Caracalla (211-217)
Roman, 215-217 AD
From Rome Italy.

Caracalla was the son of Septimius Seberus. He began ruling with his bother Geta but murdered him after a year. In 212 Caracalla granted citizenship to all freeborn people in the Empire. In 217 he was murdered (whilst relieving himself,) during a campaign in the East, by an officer whose brother he had executed.

  1. 7-3.102 (Sculpture 1917)

author: TheNewHobbyist

title: Creeper Valentine Action Figure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This mini figure is perfect for your desktop just in time for valentines day. Put it there to remind yourself that somewhere out there, there's a creeper that loves you.
Designed to be assembled, this creeper has 5 points of articulation. Wow!

Designed to be printed with no support! These joint pins are 18 sided polygons for the "indexed" feel.
I changed the name from statue to action figure because...it moves!
Printing Instructions:
Pins: Solid (100% Infill) {edit Added as separate .stl for those slicers that can't separate}
Head: 3 shells, 20% Infill
Torso: 3 shells, 20% Infill
Legs: 1 shell, 50% Infill 5 points of articulation are:
Front Left Leg
Front Right Leg
Rear Left Leg
Rear Right Leg
Head The creeper statuette measures approximately 4.65 inches overall fully assembled. EDIT
My printer could not make the leg pins successfully. I purchased a small pack of Brads/Escutcheon Pins: Size 3/4" x 14 Item # 532628 from Hillman Group. I then pressed these into the torso; the legs stay GREAT. You might need to drill the hole in the torso deeper depending on your infill %.
I will be modifying this in the future to fix this as I get more knowledge into slip fits and how to make small versions of pins that actually hold. I'll look into something such as the gear heart pins.

Updated on 1-Jan-2016: Released a wheel mount for 25GA370 Motor
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1238317 Update on 17-Sep-2014: Release a wheel mount for Tamiya 72001 Planetary Gearbox Kit
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:466438
.
With a 3d printer, Omni-wheel is easy to make. However, number of choice is little in Internet.
This project aim to produce Omni-wheel for small scale robot project that:
  • Able to produce more than 80% of its functional parts by 3d Printer.
    2.For the remaining 20% of material, they should be easily available with low price
  • Able to assembly with tools available at home.
  • Easy to develop accessory for this wheel to adapt to different gearbox, servo motors.
    Please feel free to provide feed back.
    .
    Testing:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WQ2d-EvYX10

Print with high resolution (0.1mm layer height), 20% infill.
  • 2 x Trial3_3.stl
  • 12 x ConcaveWheel_0.3.stl
    The following additional material are required for each wheel:
  • 1 x 20mm M3 screw
  • 2 x 10mm M3 screw
  • 12 x O-ring (RS Part number : 128928)
  • 12 x 3mm plastic/Metal rod (1cm in length, I am using Tamiya ITEM70133)
  • 48 x M3 Plastic washer
  • Super glue (for fixing the O-ring to ConcaveWheel)

I came up with this simple mount for a EZstruder cold end with Kysan NEMA 17 stepper. Designed with my OpenBeam Mini Kossel in mind, it could be used with just about any extrusion. The EZstruder bolts to the arm of the mount with M3 screws, which are also used to attach the mount to the printer. The stepper itself is attached only to the EZstruder, so I also added a tab/shelf to support the bottom of the stepper.

I printed the part on a MakerBot Dual in ABS with three shells and 20% infill.  In use, I've noticed a small amount of flex in the mount when my deltas effector platform is furthest from the extruder. Printing with a higher amount of infill may eliminate this problem, but I solved it by removing the cable ties I had on the Bowden tube that were close to the mount.

This is a Roof rack inspired by the ARB Deluxe Defender/Discovery 1 & 2 Steel Roof Rack 1100 x 1350.
I used this to base the design upon. The roof rack measures 110 mm by 135 mm.
This is a working progress which I printed with a 25% infill and a course support material.
The mounts to fix the roof rack are designed to be a temporary measure and just "clip" onto the roof edging but feel free to develop something that is better =). Print 2
press fit some m8 nuts (5/8ths)
thread one onto an m8 rod
toss on a spool of filament
Thread the other onto the rod and screw it down hard, clamping the spool in place.
Then I use a couple m8 nuts on the ends to make sure the whole thing has a fair bit of friction because I don't want the filament spool freewheeling and unwinding on me.
